originalText.text: Absolutely amazing! The plants were so reasonably priced and the food was outstanding!!! I had the portabello mushroom soup & avocado bread - the mushroom soup was the best i've ever had! Will definitely visit again every time in NYC!

text.text: Absolutely amazing! The plants were so reasonably priced and the food was outstanding!!! I had the portabello mushroom soup & avocado bread - the mushroom soup was the best i've ever had! Will definitely visit again every time in NYC!

originalText.text: I am an architect with 25 years of experience, and pains me to see what these landscape architects did to our complex, Morningside Gardens. They detailed the whole project with these enormous smooth-concrete curbs that stick out of the landscaping like the Great Wall of China, thousands of feet of it. Coupled with white concrete walkways EVERYWHERE, our walkways now look like a parking lot or a driveway in suburban NJ. Thank god that the original architects contoured al the walkways and tree openings. What is worst, they are replacing the ramp-stairs - that our elderly and people with carts used with great success - with a 3-step + landing version instead, destroying the mid-century modernist legacy (complex designed by Harrison & Abramovitz) and increasing the difficulty of usage. In addition, the stair curb profile is now a jagged, instead of a straight line, creating conflict with the surrounding landscape. Speaking to other landscape architects, I found out that the ramp-stairs are not only legal, but preferred to stairs for their ease of use, while blending better with the landscape. They also seemed to have increased the amount of impervious area (created a heliport in the middle of an existing lawn for our senior citizens to practice Circumambulation, maybe?), created enormous amount of construction debris and noise (what happened to the concept of adaptive reuse?), and created a monumental staircase connecting two buildings in the complex, staircase that would befit a stadium, not a low-traffic residential area. What happened with green design and sustainability? When is the LPC going to start protecting notable landscape designs from unappreciative residents and their wiling helpers?

originalText.text: I think this place is permanently closed. I dont see any Terrain near by there
